importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Richard Kenneth Djerf committed the murders of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
The date of Djerf's execution, marking Arizona's second execution of the year and part of a broader national context of recent executions.
A previous execution in Arizona was botched, leading to public criticism and a temporary halt in executions due to concerns over the protocol and drug administration.
Executions resumed in Arizona after a hiatus, with three executions occurring in 2022, signaling a revival of the state’s capital punishment practices.
A pause in executions occurred in 2023 due to a review ordered by Governor Katie Hobbs and Attorney General Kris Mayes, reflecting ongoing political and ethical debates over the death penalty.
The review of execution procedures ended in November 2024, with Governor Hobbs dismissing a federal magistrate and reforms implemented in the lethal injection team.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame of the crime, highlighting the long duration of the case — over 30 years — which reflects the lengthy legal process and public attention.
The recent execution of Djerf occurs within a broader national trend of executions being carried out in 2025, including in other U.S. states, indicating a resurgence in capital punishment.
The period during which Arizona conducted a review of its death penalty protocols, leading to changes in execution procedures and reactivation of executions.

keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 killing of four Luna family members in Phoenix.
The execution was the second in Arizona that year and the fourth in the U.S. during the week, reflecting broader national execution activity.
Djerf allegedly committed the murders in revenge for a prior theft, sexually assaulting Rochelle Luna and fatally attacking the rest of the family.
The execution process took about 10 minutes, with Djerf’s veins being suboptimal, and required multiple IV attempts, raising concerns about execution efficiency and human dignity.
Arizona has faced criticism over past botched executions and delays, including a 2014 case where Joseph Wood received 15 doses over two hours, leading to prolonged suffering.
The state has paused executions twice since 2014 due to ethical and procedural concerns, with a review ending in November 2024 and new protocols implemented.
The execution of Djerf marks the continuation of a 107-person death row in Arizona, with five more executions scheduled nationally in 2025.
Attorney General Kris Mayes supported the execution, stating that the victims and their families deserve justice and closure.

namedEntities.name: Richard Kenneth Djerf
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A convicted murderer executed in Arizona for the 1993 killing of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure of the article, representing the execution of a long-pending death row case and symbolizing the persistence of the death penalty despite public and procedural controversies.

namedEntities.name: Albert Luna Sr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A victim of the 1993 killings in Phoenix, murdered during the attack on the Luna family home.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His death, along with three others, forms the core of the crime and the moral gravity of the case, emphasizing the loss of innocent lives.

namedEntities.name: Patricia Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A victim of the 1993 killings, fatally shot and tied to a kitchen chair at the Luna home.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her death illustrates the brutality and premeditated nature of the crime, highlighting the targeted violence against family members.

namedEntities.name: Rochelle Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 18-year-old daughter of the Luna family, sexually assaulted and killed during the attack.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her inclusion in the victims underscores the heinous nature of the crime, particularly the sexual assault component, which increases the moral and public outrage.

namedEntities.name: Damien Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 5-year-old son of the Luna family, tied to a kitchen chair and fatally shot.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His death emphasizes the atrocity of the crime, particularly its impact on innocent children and the violation of family safety.

namedEntities.name: Albert Luna Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A family member of the Luna family who was not present during the killings but was allegedly blamed by Djerf for a previous theft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role in the crime narrative shows how Djerf’s obsession with revenge stemmed from a false accusation, adding a layer of injustice to the case.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. state where the murders occurred and where the execution took place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state is central to the legal and ethical debate around capital punishment, having faced criticism for botched executions and procedural delays over the years.

namedEntities.name: Phoenix
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The city in Arizona where the murder of the Luna family occurred.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location grounds the crime in a specific geographic and cultural context, linking it to local law enforcement and community memory.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Arizona Attorney General who supported the execution of Richard Djerf.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key political figure advocating for capital punishment, and her support underscores the state's continued commitment to the death penalty despite past controversies.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Wood
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A previous prisoner executed in Arizona in 2014, whose execution was botched and led to public criticism.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His case exemplifies past failures in Arizona’s execution procedures and contributed to the state’s temporary pause in executions.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Brian Gunches
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A previous prisoner executed in Arizona in March 2025 for the 2002 killing of Ted Price.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His execution precedes Djerf’s, showing that Arizona has resumed executions after a hiatus and is actively carrying out death sentences again.

namedEntities.name: Death Penalty Information Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An organization that tracks executions across the United States.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides context about the broader national execution trend, indicating that five more executions are scheduled in 2025, including in Florida, Alabama, Oklahoma, and Tennessee.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix — including Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, 18-year-old Rochelle Luna, and 5-year-old Damien Luna. Djerf, who had been in prison for over 29 years, allegedly committed the killings in revenge for a prior theft he blamed on Albert Luna Jr., a family member who did not witness the crime. The execution, the state’s second of the year and fourth in the country that week, involved a prolonged IV insertion process due to suboptimal veins, raising concerns about execution procedures. Arizona has faced criticism for past botched executions, including a 2014 case involving Joseph Wood, and has paused executions twice since 2014. The state resumed executions in 2022, with three executions that year, and again in 2025 after a review in 2024. The case underscores ongoing ethical and procedural debates about the death penalty, while also highlighting the long-term impact of capital punishment on victims' families and public trust.
title: Arizona Executes Man for Killing 4 Members of a Family in Phoenix in 1993
